isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Service (1991) - CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE - CRANKCASE (Reconditioning) - INSPECTION AND REPAIR

step1.para: Visually inspect crankcase, after cleaning, for scoring, roughness or wear at the cylinder bores. Also check for cracks or water leaks.
Check for cracks using a spray dye penetrant method of crack detection. (A 3 step method: cleaner, dye and developer).

step2.para: Replace the crankcase if cracked; do not attempt to weld.

step1.para: Check the top surface of the crankcase for flatness. Using a straightedge, check by attempting to insert a.003 in. feeler gauge ribbon between the straightedge and crankcase head surface. IF THIS IS POSSIBLE, REPLACE THE CRANKCASE.

Check cylinder bore out-of-round and taper using an accurate dial bore gauge as shown in Figure 6.41
.

Measure the diameter of the cylinder bore at the top of the piston ring travel at a right angle " A", Figure 6.42
to the centerline of the crankshaft. Record the readings. Next, measure each bore so the gauge reading coincides with the centerline "B", Figure 6.42
of the crankshaft. Record that reading. The difference between "A" and "B" is the out-of-round condition at the top of the cylinder bore. Repeat the same procedure at the bottom of the ring travel to check for out-of-round condition. (See "SPECIFICATIONS".).

With the reading recorded in step 5, determine the taper of the bore by determining the difference between the diameters measured at the "top" and "bottom" of the bore as shown in the Figure 6.43
. (See "SPECIFICATIONS".).

note.para: To determine taper, use measurements made at right angles to the centerline of the crankshaft.

step1.para: If the cylinder bore is within the specifications, use new standard size pistons and rings. Refer to Section 5.

note.para: Refinish cylinders that are deeply scored and/or when out-of-round and/or taper exceeds specifications.

step1.para: If cylinder walls have minor surface damage, but out-of-round and taper are within limits, it may be possible to remove such damage by honing cylinder walls and installing new service pistons, providing piston clearance is within specified limits. Refer to Section 5.
If cylinder bore is suitable for use without reconditioning, deglaze the bore using glaze breaker brush then reassemble.

important.para: IF THE CYLINDER BORES ARE TO BE DEGLAZED, THE PISTON COOLING JET TUBES MUST BE REMOVED.

step1.para:
Cylinder bore can be deglazed using a 120 grit (no color code) glaze breaker brush such as the BRM Flex Honer (see Note) GBD4-1/8. ( Figure 6.44
).

note.para: Order the BRM Flex Honer GBD4-1/8 directly from:

step1.para: This Silicone carbide-tipped nylon flexible brush quickly deglazes cylinder walls and produces a crosshatch pattern on the cylinder wall surface in a single operation. The brush contours itself to the cylinder wall and conditions the wall surface without altering the cylinder bore.

note.para: It is good practice to rotate the crankshaft, prior to deglazing, so the journal is at its lowest point in the bore.

step1.para: Obtain a 12 oz. can of PE-12 "Solvent and Penetrating Fluid" manufactured by AGS, available at any well-stocked auto supply house. This spray contains colloidal graphite and has a black appearance. Spray both the cylinder to be deglazed and the flex hone.

Deglaze the cylinder as follows: (Refer to Figure 6.45
)

step2.para: Attach the flex hone to an electric or air powered drill WITH ADJUSTABLE SPEED.

important.para: A SPEED OF APPROXIMATELY 100-200 RPM IS REQUIRED. SPEED ADJUSTMENT IS REQUIRED FOR THE PROCEDURE TO BE SUCCESSFUL.

step2.para: Hone the cylinder wall for about 3 seconds while stroking up and down at a rate of one up and down stroke per second.

Withdraw the flex hone from the cylinder bore while the hone is rotating. Wipe a portion of the cylinder wall and visually inspect the crosshatch pattern comparing it to an untouched cylinder bore ( Figure 6.46
).

note.para: The crosshatch pattern should be approximately 45°. Visual comparison with a "virgin" bore is best, provided the engine has not been previously repaired.

step2.para: If the pattern is "flatter" than required, increase the up and down stroke speed or slow down the drill rotation.
Continue deglazing the cylinder bore (after adjusting your technique) for an additional 10-15 seconds (approximately 20-25 strokes).

important.para: DURING THE DEGLAZING, AN ASSISTANT MUST CONTINUALLY SPRAY THE PE-12 "SOLVENT AND PENETRATING FLUID" BY AGS, ONTO THE CYLINDER WALL.

step2.para:
Wipe the cylinder bore clean and once again visually inspect the bore for the proper 45° crosshatch pattern ( Figure 6.46
).

step1.para: After deglazing, thoroughly clean the cylinder bores using soap and water, dry with filtered compressed air and re-oil using clean engine oil.

However, if the wear exceeds the taper and out-of-round limits, it is recommended to rebore the cylinder or cylinders to within 0.003 in. of the required oversize diameter, Figure 6.47
. This will allow enough stock for the final step of honing the bores, Figure 6.48
, so that the exact clearance may be obtained for the selected oversize piston. When performing the honing operation, the hone should be stroked up and down to produce a crosshatch pattern on the cylinder wall as shown in Figure 6.46
. The faster the hone rotates, the faster it must be stroked up and down to produce the desired crosshatch pattern.

important.para: PISTON COOLING JET TUBES MUST BE REMOVED FOR REBORING AND HONING OPERATIONS.

note.para: After the honing operation is completed, the sharp burred edge that develops at the top and bottom of a newly honed cylinder should be removed manually with emery cloth. Then thoroughly clean the block and cylinder bores.

step1.para: After the honing operation is completed, thoroughly clean the cylinder bores using soap and water. Dry with filtered compressed air and re-oil using clean engine oil.

note.para: Failure to properly clean the cylinder bores can result in rapid engine wear and piston ring failure.

step1.para: It it becomes necessary to remove an expansion plug due to water leaks, drill a 1/2 in. hole in the center of the plug and remove by prying with a small pry bar.

Install the new expansion plugs with the concave side toward the engine. Coat the edges of the plug with Aviation Permatext No. 3. Use expansion plug replacer ZTSE4155A which consists of a driver and driver sleeve which accurately indents the expansion plugs upon striking with a hammer.

note.para: With crankcase disassembled, inspect the camshaft bushings and service as described in Section 4.
